titleStmt.title: M49. [Anon: Anon died around 1477...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned, and undated. 8p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M49. [Anon: Anon died around 1477...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned, and undated. 8p. Paginated 3-10. On verso of p. 8-9 her: People one would have liked to have met. Holograph fragment. 2p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.s: died round 18787. It was the printed book with the authors name attached that killed him. After that the audience was separate from the singer. After that the song was attached to the singer. Anon gives place to xmxmxmxmxmx or or Peter; he lives in a house and he has books.

div.p: [The heart of this vast prolieferation (proliferation) of printed pages remains the song. The song has the same power over the reader in the 20th cen ury (century) as over the hearer in the 11th. To enjoy singing, to enjoy hearing the sing, must be the most deep rooted, the toughest of human instincts comparable for persistency with the instinct of self preservation It is indeed the instinct of self preservation. Only when we put two and two together--two pencil strokes, two written words, two bricks do we overcome doissolution (dissolution) and set up some stake against oblivion. The passion with which we seek out these creation (creations) and attempt endlessly, perpetually, to make them is of a piece with the instinct that sets us preserving out (our) bodies, with clothes, food, roofs, from destruction.]

But With the broughtcame into existence forces that cover over the original song--books themselves, and the readers of books. If science were so advanced that we could at this moment X ray the singers mind as she moved we should find a nimbus surrounding the song; a steeam ([stream? steam?]) of influences. Some we can name--education; class; the pressure of society. But they are so many, and so

interwoven and so obscure that it is simpler to invent for them nonsense names--- say and . Nin Crot and Pully are always at their work, tugging, obscuring, distorting. Some are visible only to the writer. Others only to the reader. More and more omplex (complex) do they become as time passes. The song beneath is only to be disocovered (discovered) in a flash of recognition; Some say they feel it when their beards bristle; others that a thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh. But the song is there still. For example:

That babbling, child like, story telling singer, that gossip at the farm yard door, that inno ent (innocent) eyed, naked, lustful, nowalternately obscene n (and) devout singer, who was now and ag a great artist died in 14787, And with him died the part of his song that the audience sang--the voice that filled in pauses, and added sometimes a nonsenical (nonsensical) chorus To follow his fortunes further we must turn to one of those commentators who tell us us so much about the invisible influences. about Nin Crot and Pulley.
But for him of course we have to wait until winter was past; until time has drawn its blue veil

over the horizon; until there is a past. ThenWhen Anon is lomg (long) dead, adnthe (and the) Pil have gone their way, somebody looks back. He is a representative man, that is he hxxxxx is often repeated, in other centuries, with little variation. He-- was his name-- is the first of that long line of leisured and learned men who have time to think about the past in hthe (the) quiet of the parsonage. Like , like the parson of , hehad a library; and dug up coins. He already sees the present against the background of the past. The past has necome (become) so settled, so ordered, that yhe (the) present looks ungainly and degenerate against it. There is too much comfort; too much silver; too many pillows. The young , are not the men their father (fathers)
were. The smoke is drawn off from their sitting rooms by chimensy (chimneys), so that instead of being salted and
hardned (hardened) by thesmoke eddying from the fire in the brazier, they are tender and subject to rheumatism. They dress most fantastically comparded (compared) with their ancestors.

But the English seen past as seen by Harrison only served to show up the physical, the material change --the change that had come over houses, furniuture (furniture) and clothing. To show up the change in the mind, there was no English pattern. There was no English literature, to show up the decline of English literature. "English " says the " had gone undergrounf (underground) for two centuries...
English had gon (gone) down stairs into the kitchen, into the farmyard. had sung his song at the back door in a jargon that was as uncouth to as to ourslves (ourselves):
Icham for woing al forwake Wery no water in wore
An hendy hap ichable yghent Ichot from hevene it is me sent

-- yhhe (the) words were as difficult for him to spell out as for ourselves; and more painful. For they reminded him of his lack of intellectual ansctery (ancestry). He goes back a very little way - to
, , . For him it was a very sxxxx little way. So, to have anscestors (ancestors), he must cross the ; his ancestors by way o f (of) the mind are the Greeks and the Romans. His page is burdened particularly [illeg.]with these proofs of good breeding. Hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm , ; ; --they prove his good breeding, as we prove ours by going vback (back) to , to . The anicents (ancients) occupied the same place in
mind that the Elizabethans occupy in ours. Those were the great books that were chained to the
selves (shelves) of the college libraries. The learned read them. And in Harrisons day the nobles. "...our ancient ladies of the court" were to be found reading th (the) holy scriptures as they did their needlwwork (needlework); and histories. The noble ladies wxmxmxmmxmxx if they had a turn for rading (reading), must read Latin and reek (Greek), for xxxxmxmxmx English literature xmxmxmmxmxmxmxxxxmxmxmxx not nough (enough) English literature to keep a healthy appetite in being. They had to learn
French, and Latin, and many were driven by hunger to master Greek.

In the minds background then stood the almost featureless Roman busts-- , ; ; overpowering , and and . And in the foreground there is the house, no longer a hut made of branches; no longer thick with smoke; There is a pillow now, instead of the old log with the hollow in it; and glass in the windows; and silver to drink from. The ceilings are curiously worked . Beyond the house there is ; a fine city; and [illeg.] ships riding at anchor; and Inns upon the raod (road) and there though he cannot see himself, is , querulous yet kindly, using languag (language) to his patron that would have schoked (shocked) his
anecsotrs (ancestors) -- words as ornate as the carvings and
decorati s (decorations) that shocked him. And he digs in the earth for coins has never gone more than forty miles from in ; has a father; and owns a mastiff. The age of anonymity is over when we begin to furnish out the individualwriter with xmxmxxx his own private features.

p.sup:
CXI
"with vain affectation of eloquence to paint out a rotten sepulchre

div.p: But how little even the most diligent, the most laborious, of these searchers can find o (of) the human being. They polish the shell only. They lingerremain upon the habits and the furniture, the house itself, It is as if we were told that the novelist had a tweed suit, six hats, some bowlers some top hats; and used to take a walking stick in his hand and when he walked; and had his meat cooked on a coal fire, by a woman whose name was perhaps Joan. It is the hous t (house that) they preserve with all their friction; not the tenant of the house. Save for and and for the voice of singing at the back door the English might e be a dumb race who enjoyed and suffered tacitly; a race of merchants, soldiers and preists (priests), who left behind them stone houses, cu lt vated (cultivated) fields and vast cathedrals. but not words. The great house is silent; Only the furniture remains, stiff and ornate, fanatstic (fantastic) and uncushioned.

At [illeg.]old sat at her table writing But her letter to is as intricate and foral (formal) as a [illeg.] state paper. It is a letter written from the pulpit She admonishes and preaches. She is violent and irate. xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm.They are letters from a counsellor to a conferedate (confederate); with [admonishing?] a [illeg.] full of the wickedness of men, the dangers and decits (deceits) of the world; and the praise of her [illeg.] God. "God keep us sound inmthe (in the) faith and send us health and a care to please God above all...." [illeg.] She drops into Greek and Latin. If she ha (has) to decend (descend) the actual in a [illeg.] starbeery (strawberry)
stra erry (strawberry) it w h (withwish) warning and craft. "I have sent them by

p.hi: People one wd (would) have liked to have met

div.p: : not face to face; but with a pane of glass between us Not in her [illeg.], but at : passing [left?] & The first roads wd (would) have
An adventure

boy of my kr chen (kitchen), a shrwed (shrewd)-witted boy and prettily ca cachetizes, but yet an untoward crafty boy.... Be bot (not) speddy (speedy) of speech, not (nor) tal (talk) suddenly, but where disctretion (discretion) requireth, and that soberly then...Let not Lawson, that fox, be acquanited (acquainted) with my letters..." & [illeg.]
The sound of the Bible is in her ears, her prose takes its solemn pleats; and the prose of the bible will not adapt [illeg.] itself to the natural, to the easy, to the colloquial. It is a garment to be put on when the mind is erect and dignified.

The writer therefore, conscious of his plbeian (plebian) birth hesitated on the threshold of the great room.
Thw riter (The writer) therefore, who had only lately emerged from anonymy (anonymity) hesitated on the threshold of the great room. He was now separate from his audience; but he was after all,
cloesly (closely) connected with it. He was [finally?] still unspecialised, undifferentiated. The eye was stimulated by the crimsons and golds and greesn (greens) of the clothing. by the angles and the patterns on the ceiling. The ear too was stimulated and filled. Books were read aloud; each word was given

given sharpness and substance by the speaking voice. And there was the pear shaped lute. Lilt, rhythm, melody was added to the substance and sharpness of words. In his mind there was a His mind was full of half born, still adhesive, undifferentiated words still; old words; new words; French words; Latin words. No grammar bound them tightly ogether (together). They could stretch ; they could refelc (reflect) many colours; follow many tunes; they could take the rhym (rhythm) of the lute; they could sxxxxxxxx be danced to, or sung to. But They could not yet rhtym (rhythm) of the speaking voice. [Whether he was to wrote (write) or to sing or to paint was an open question. [The arts were closely related] For a moment there is a pause on the threshold of the great Elizabthan (Elizabethan) room. when the artist is not wholly writer, wholly painter, or wholly musician. was the natural product of that momentary pause on the threshold.

It seems possible for a moment that the great English art is going to be painting, or music. not literature And then for soem (some) reason make (makes) his choice; the great English art is to be poetry.
